item.title: 8 Most Beloved Elder Scrolls Characters, Ranked
item.description:
Summary

  • Iconic Elder Scrolls NPCs like Neloth and Lucien Lachance are memorable for their unique personalities and fan impact.
  • Characters like Saint Jiub and M'aiq the Liar became beloved for their quirks and indirect impact on the player's experience.
  • Key characters like Dagoth Ur, Serana, Paarthurnax, and Sheogorath add depth, emotion, and humor to the rich lore of The Elder Scrolls.

After many decades at the top of its game, The Elder Scrolls franchise is known for its vast worlds, deep lore, and unforgettable characters. Across Morrowind , Oblivion , and Skyrim , players have met a pantheon of personalities, some quirky, some terrifying, and some so iconic they’ve become synonymous with Tamriel's unique universe.

These NPCs, ranked by fan impact, story depth, and memorability, have earned a special place in fans' hearts. Whether they are widely loved for their power, humor, or tragic backstories, these characters have helped shape the Elder Scrolls experience for millions. It would take a mortal with a heart as dark as Sithis or as empty as Malacath's Ash Pit to forget them.

8 Neloth - Morrowind

The Sassiest Sorcerer In All Of Solstheim

Introduced in Morrowind and returning in Skyrim ’s "Dragonborn" DLC after his home in Morrowind was destroyed, Neloth of House Telvanni is a powerful wizard who treats everyone (from the Nerevarines of Morrowind to Dovahkiins of Skyrim 's "Dragonborn" DLC) as if they're one fungal spore short of a mycological breakthrough.

Besides Neloth's magical prowess and massive mushroom tower, he is often warmly remembered for his delightfully dry insults and unapologetic superiority complex. He’s the grumpy wizard archetype with an Arrogance skill level of 110, and fans adore him for it, whether he’s casually demanding that legendary heroes source staff for his mushroom laboratory or casually dissecting the ethics of soul-trapping.

7 Lucien Lachance - Oblivion

The Lucious Voice In The Void That Fans Still Hear In Their Sleep

It is highly unlikely that anyone would be happy to see this master assassin sneak up to the end of their bed before greeting them with a husky whisper, but it is exactly for this reason that many players would consider Lucien Lachance one of their all-time favorites.

As the Speaker of the Dark Brotherhood's Black Hand, Lucien is responsible for recruiting new members into the shadowy ranks. He memorably contacts the player personally by finding them wherever they sleep (even in Oblivion's deepest, most labyrinthine dungeons). His popularity was cemented with his return (or at least his ghost's return) in Skyrim .

6 Saint Jiub, Eradicator of the Winged Menace - Morrowind

From Prisoner To Patron Saint

Before dragons, before Daedric Princes, before even tutorial prompts and character classes, there was Jiub. This unassuming Dunmer prisoner greets the player's character at the start of Morrowind , asking their name as they awaken aboard a swaying prison ship. It's a fleeting interaction, but for many, Jiub became an accidental legend.

The developers at Bethesda never forgot him, and neither did the community. By the time of Skyrim , Jiub returns as a full-fledged Saint: Saint Jiub the Eradicator, hero of the people, slayer of the Cliff Racers that tormented so many people, including the Neverine. Jiub is undying proof that greatness can come from anywhere (even from the back of a prison ship in Seyda Neen).

5 M'aiq The Liar - Morrowind, Oblivion, And Skyrim

The Khajiit Who Knows Too Much (Or Nothing at All)

Wandering alone across the provinces of Tamriel, M’aiq the Liar is one of the series’ strangest constants, and one of its most cherished. This robed Khajiit appears in nearly every Elder Scrolls game since Morrowind , offering odd commentary, cryptic observations, and tongue-in-cheek jabs at both lore and game mechanics. He’s not a quest-giver, a villain, or a companion, just a traveler with tales that might be true (but probably aren’t).

M’aiq's belovedness stems from his tendency to blur the line between player and game, meta and immersion. He’s both an in-joke for longtime fans and a living reminder that Tamriel doesn’t always take itself too seriously (something that the Oblivion Remaster, with all its whimsical style intact, recently affirmed). In all his comments on marriage mods, spears, or cliff racers, M’aiq gives players a smile, a shrug, and the sense that someone out there is watching all this nonsense unfold with amusement.

4 Dagoth Ur - Morrowind

The Antagonist Fans Can't Stop Dreaming (Or Meming) About

While The Elder Scrolls ' villains have always had sympathetic (or at least nuanced) elements to them, Dagoth Ur, Morrowind 's final boss and major antagonist, might have one of the most understandable motivations, despite his divine insanity. Deep beneath Red Mountain, he speaks like an old friend returned, inviting the player to join his dream of reshaping Tamriel. His mix of charisma, madness, and mythic grandeur stems from betrayal at the hands of the Tribunal, a twisted desire for justice, and a merging with the heart of a dead god.

Decades after his emergence, Dagoth Ur's legacy endures through a wave of AI-voiced memes that remix his speeches into breastplate-busting funnies. Meme or no meme, lines like "Come, Nerevar, friend or traitor, come," are now part of gaming culture, and although Morrowind is a hard game to approach from modern gaming standards (at least without mods to modernize the experience), Dagoth Ur still whispers to us from the Heart.

3 Serana - Skyrim (Dawnguard)

Everyone's Favorite Daughter Of Coldharbour

Serana made an immediate impact with her introduction of Skyrim 's "Dawnguard" DLC. A pure-blood vampire bound up in ancient prophecy and family betrayal, she stands apart from other side characters for her dry humor, complex emotions, and unusually reactive dialogue. It also helps that she turns into one of the most dependable companions, even aiding the Last Dragonborn in their journey into the Soul Cairn and/or transformation into a vampire lord.

Many fans don't just hold her to be beloved, but they are, in fact, in love with her. Sadly, despite the fact that Skyrim's open world offers datable and marriable NPCs, these fans were likely brokenhearted when they discovered that this thousands-of-years-old raven-haired blood drinker was uninterested in their advances, regardless of their gender, status as an undead, or availability.

2 Paarthurnax - Skyrim

The Dragon Who Chose Love And Wisdom Over Rage And Domination

When players first meet Paarthurnax atop the Throat of the World, it’s a moment of pure cinematic awe, and one made all the more surprising when the ancient dragon speaks not with fury, but with peace. As the leader of the Greybeards and a former lieutenant of Alduin, Paarthurnax is a paradox: a destroyer who chose the Way of the Voice, seeking wisdom and restraint over domination.

His gravelly voice, patient cadence, and reflective monologues have made him one of the most beloved characters in Skyrim. He is a teacher, and for many, a moral compass, thanks to lines like "What is better: to be born good, or to overcome your evil nature through great effort?" Most players' loyalty to this philosophical dragon is likely strengthened once one of The Elder Scrolls ' most hated characters, Delphine, orders the player to kill him for past crimes he has clearly repented for.

1 Sheogorath - Oblivion (The Shivering Isles)

The Daedric Prince of Chaos, Cheese, Charm, and Charisma

By Cheese, and bits of human entrails! Sheogorath, the Daedric Prince of Madness, delivers some of the series’ most quotable lines, unhinged monologues, and hilarious threats in all while ruling a realm that is literally split in two, although he probably likes it that way. Sheogorath is never entirely played off as a joke, as he is able to back up his threats if provoked.

Like the iconic Imperial Guard, Lucian Lachance, and the Arena Announcer, his memorable personality is brought to life by Wes Johnson's legendary voice work. Loving this mad god is to love oneself, as the player eventually mantles him during the closing moments of "The Shivering Isles."

item.title: 6 Best Elder Scrolls DLCs, Ranked
item.description:
Summary

  • DLCs like Hearthfire, Dawnguard, and Tribunal transformed gameplay in Skyrim and Morrowind.
  • Skyrim's expansions added domesticity, vampires, a new city, and cosmic horror.
  • Morrowind and Oblivion's DLCs expanded lore, introduced werewolves, a vampire hunt, and a realm of madness.

The Elder Scrolls series has never been shy about going big. Big worlds, big lore drops, big cheese wheels. But where the series truly shines is in its DLC. These content expansions don’t just pad the runtime, but rewrite and revamp how players engage with Tamriel.

Whether it's moving into a house the player built with their bare hands or descending into the mind of a cheese-loving Daedric Prince, these DLCs often feel like whole new games tucked inside the ones we already love. Some pushed technical boundaries. Others expanded lore in ways the base game never dared to. All of them gave players something new and exciting.

6 Skyrim: Hearthfire

A Simple House...With A Bandit Raid Every Morning

The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition
8 /10
9.0 /10
Released
October 28, 2016

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
8 /10
9.0 /10

ESRB
M For Mature 17+ Due To Blood and Gore, Intense Violence, Language, Sexual Themes, Use of Alcohol
Developer(s)
Bethesda Game Studios
Platform(s)
PC, PS4, PS5, Xbox One
Powered by

There’s something oddly charming about watching a Dragonborn — someone who can literally scream a man off a cliff — spend hours hammering nails and collecting clay. Hearthfire wasn’t the flashiest DLC, but it added a gentle domestic layer to a game best known for decapitations and dragon slaying. With this add-on, players could purchase plots of land in Falkreath, Hjaalmarch, and The Pale, and design a home from the ground up. Not just choose a house — design it. Wings could be customized into greenhouses, enchanting towers, trophy rooms, and more depending on how nerdy the player wanted to get.

Adoption also entered the picture here. Two kids could be brought home, assuming players childproofed their death fortress with some beds and a chest of toys. The whole thing felt like Skyrim decided to take a breather and let players live a post-retirement life, even if that life involved killing giants before breakfast because they wandered onto the property.

The DLC wasn't perfect. The steward AI had a death wish and bandits apparently thought homemade soup and goat cheese were worth dying for. But Hearthfire gave the world of Skyrim something no other DLC did: a sense of permanence.

5 Skyrim: Dawnguard

The Vampire DLC That Made Every Fort a Buffet Table

Dawnguard let players embrace their inner Dracula or go full Van Helsing. Either way, someone was getting disintegrated. This expansion was Skyrim’s first major DLC, and immediately justified its existence by finally making vampires more than annoying NPCs in caves. Join the ancient vampire clan of Volkihar, and players unlock the ability to turn into a grotesque flying bat-creature with teleportation powers. Side with the Dawnguard, and they get to build a faction from the ashes and wield weapons specifically crafted to take vampires down.

The DLC introduced Serana, arguably the most beloved character in the series, with actual backstory, dialogue depth, and sass. She wasn’t just another follower — she had stakes in the plot, deep ties to Molag Bal’s twisted mythology, and she wasn’t afraid to call out the player’s decisions. The Soul Cairn, an eerie dimension filled with lost souls, undead dragons, and giant soul gems, was another standout. It was a rare moment where Skyrim leaned fully into cosmic horror.

Though some parts of the DLC felt padded with radiant quests and filler dungeons, Dawnguard delivered a lore-rich, mechanically fresh storyline. It made vampires scary again — or made being one extremely fun, depending on the Dragonborn's moral compass.

4 Morrowind: Tribunal

A Capital City That Wasn't Falling Apart

The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind
9.3 /10
Released
May 1, 2002

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL

ESRB
T For Teen due to Blood, Violence
Developer(s)
Bethesda Game Studios
Platform(s)
PC, Xbox (Original)
Powered by

Before Oblivion streamlined cities and Skyrim gave players smaller hubs, Tribunal introduced Mournhold: a segmented, vertical, beautifully rendered capital city that felt alive in a way few places in Morrowind did. Unlike the mushroom towers and ash storms in Vvardenfell, this city was clean, filled with politics, clockwork soldiers, and god-tier drama. Players were no longer the outsider in a strange land, but a force tangled in a divine conspiracy featuring Almalexia, one of the Tribunal gods.

The writing was sharper here, less abstract than the base game and more steeped in moral ambiguity. Almalexia wasn't a cartoon villain. She was layered, dangerous, and tragic, especially as she descended into paranoia. It also introduced the Fabricants, biomechanical monsters that looked like they escaped from Numenera and dropped into Tamriel. And they fit perfectly.

Players got to dive deep into the politics of the Temple and were rewarded with a clearer picture of how the Tribunal maintained power — through manipulation, religious authority, and deadly secrets. It may not have had open-world sprawl, but Tribunal doubled down on narrative density, offering structured, urban storytelling.

3 Morrowind: Bloodmoon

Where The Northern Lights Meet Werewolves And Island Survival

Before Skyrim was even a whisper in Todd Howard’s mind, Bloodmoon gave players the chance to explore icy wilderness, build their own colony, and turn into a werewolf. Solstheim was a brutal, snowy frontier filled with frost trolls, Nordic ruins, and Stalhrim — an ice-like material that would later become a staple in Skyrim . What set Bloodmoon apart wasn’t just its new setting, but how dynamic it felt. Raven Rock, a barely-there mining settlement at the start of the DLC, could be developed into a bustling colony. Choices actually changed the world. And then, of course, there was Hircine’s Hunt.

At a time when Daedric Princes were mostly associated with weird fetch quests, Bloodmoon gave players a full-on werewolf survival arc, leading to a deadly game hosted by the Daedric Lord of the Hunt himself. Becoming a werewolf wasn’t just a throwaway gimmick — it transformed how players moved, fought, and survived. It came with drawbacks, too. Transforming meant losing access to gear and, if caught mid-maul in town, losing any chance at a normal life.

Bloodmoon didn’t just expand Morrowind geographically; it expanded its tone. It was colder, more primal, and filled with long silences broken only by blizzards and the occasional scream in the woods.

2 Skyrim: Dragonborn

Players Returned To Morrowind, And Had No Idea What Hit Them

Everything about Dragonborn screamed nostalgia — then immediately slapped it out of players with tentacles. Set on the island of Solstheim, the same icy outpost from Bloodmoon , this DLC brought Skyrim full circle. But instead of leaning on familiarity, it introduced Miraak, the first Dragonborn, who had no problem brainwashing entire villages and building Lovecraftian towers with the help of Hermaeus Mora.

This was the DLC where players got to explore Apocrypha, a plane of existence made of writhing books, green slime, and floating squid-robots. It was surreal, creepy, and unlike anything Skyrim had done before. Learning the Black Books gave players new shouts and powers, often in exchange for a trip through something that felt more like Silent Hill than The Elder Scrolls . Dragon riding was also introduced here, though calling it “riding” might be generous. It was more like awkwardly hovering while hoping the AI would figure out what to attack. Still, having the ability was cool enough.

What made Dragonborn essential wasn’t just the new content; it was the way it rewrote what players thought they knew about their powers. Suddenly, being Dragonborn wasn’t unique anymore. There were deeper, darker roots to it all, and Hermaeus Mora was whispering in the background.

1 Oblivion: Shivering Isles

Madness Never Looked So Stylish

The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion
34
8.9 /10
Released
March 20, 2006

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL

ESRB
M for Mature: Blood and Gore, Language, Sexual Themes, Use of Alcohol, Violence
Developer(s)
Bethesda
Platform(s)
PC, PS3, Xbox 360
Powered by

It started with a door in the middle of Niben Bay. Not a quest marker. Not a main story push. Just… a door. Open it, and players are whisked away to the domain of Sheogorath, the Daedric Prince of Madness, in what is still considered one of the boldest expansions in RPG history. Shivering Isles wasn’t just new content; it was a new game within a game.

Split between the unsettling perfection of Mania and the grotesque decay of Dementia, the Isles were a visual and tonal masterpiece. Every NPC was slightly (or extremely) unhinged, and every quest twisted expectations. A paranoid man who wanted players to kill everyone in town before they killed him. A museum of oddities. A festival of forced suicide. It was dark humor served on a silver platter with eyeballs for garnish.

The main quest slowly transforms the player into the new Sheogorath, in a rare example of an RPG DLC completely rewriting the protagonist’s identity. The transformation wasn’t just cosmetic either. It shifted how the world reacted to the player, cementing them as a literal god of chaos by the time the credits rolled. No other Elder Scrolls DLC has dared to go this far, this weird, or this wonderfully mad.

item.title: 10 Best Western RPGS For JRPG Fans
item.description:
Summary

  • Western RPGs like The Witcher 3 and Baldur's Gate 3 offer complex stories and character development for JRPG fans to enjoy.
  • Games like Divinity: Original Sin 2 and Pillars of Eternity 2 provide similar party dynamics and deep story elements found in JRPGs.
  • Engaging with unique RPGs like Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 allows players to experience innovative real-time combat, reminiscent of JRPGs.

The RPG genre is one of the most intricate and rich video game genres in terms of history and variety. When many fans hear the term RPG, they think of JRPGs . These games are characterized most prominently by the region where they are created and developed, as well as by genre hallmarks such as turn-based combat and an emphasis on party dynamics.

RPGs come in many forms, but JRPGs like Final Fantasy and Dragon Quest are enduring, both in their legacy and in their design. A lot of RPGs, even ones that are wildly different in terms of gameplay, take inspiration from these games that JRPG fans can resonate with. Here are ten of the best Western RPGs that JRPG fans will also enjoy.

10 Haven

Playing Together

Haven
Adventure
RPG
Systems
Released
December 3, 2020

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M
Powered by

Haven is a small sci-fi indie RPG about two lovers fleeing an authoritarian government. As protagonists Yu and Kay learn more about the secluded world to which they've escaped, they must contend with emissaries from the evil government as well as strange alien threats.

While Haven 's party size is certainly much smaller than most JRPGs, the focus on Yu and Kay's relationship and development will be very familiar to anyone who's ever embarked on a party-based quest. The real-time combat is another departure from JRPGs, but the coordination between Yu and Kay makes for some engaging strategic play.

9 The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt

Toss A Coin

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt
9 /10
45
9.4 /10
Released
May 19, 2015

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
9 /10
45
9.4 /10

ESRB
M for Mature: Use of Alcohol, Blood and Gore, Intense Violence, Nudity, Strong Language, Strong Sexual Content
Powered by

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is one of the most prominent Western RPGs on the market, and its open-world design and action-oriented gameplay are emblematic of the sort of design Western RPGs tend to favor. However, there's still a lot to enjoy for JRPG fans. The game's expansive story and richly detailed fantasy world let it stand tall alongside classics like Dragon Quest .

While The Witcher 3 's combat and character progression aren't the same as what's typically seen in JRPGs, the sense of growth and development should feel very familiar. The Witcher 3 is one of the most iconic Western RPGs for good reason, and JRPG fans will likely enjoy it just as much.

8 Legend Of Grimrock 2

Going Old School

Legend of Grimrock 2
RPG
Systems
Released
October 15, 2014

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
t
Powered by

Legend of Grimrock 2 is a throwback to some of the earliest RPGs on the market; challenging dungeon crawls with imposing foes, devious puzzles, and lethal traps. While most modern RPGs are more forgiving, the inspiration they drew from these old classics remains extremely present, especially in turn-based JRPGs.

These turn-based games have a lot in common with Legend of Grimrock 2 . Combat is more real-time in this game, but party members still take turns, and they each have a separate class, allowing them to specialize in different attacks and combat techniques. Finding powerful new weapons and spells for each character is one of the greatest thrills in Legend of Grimrock 2 , and that's something any JRPG fan can appreciate.

7 Star Wars: Knights Of The Old Republic

A Galaxy Far, Far Away

Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic
10
9.0 /10
Released
July 15, 2003

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
T for Teen: Violence
Powered by

Despite its age, Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic remains one of the most prominent and beloved video games set in the iconic Star Wars galaxy . This legendary RPG takes place long before the movies, focusing on the life and history of the infamous Darth Revan.

While characters in Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic act simultaneously, BioWare still took a lot of inspiration from more turn-based games to design the combat. Players will unlock powerful new abilities throughout the campaign, just as they would in a traditional JRPG, and they'll also develop relationships and connections with their party members throughout their journey.

6 Pillars Of Eternity 2: Deadfire

Across The Seas

Pillars of Eternity II: Deadfire
8.8 /10
Released
May 8, 2018

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
Mature 17+ // Blood and Gore, Nudity, Sexual Themes, Strong Language, Violence
Powered by

While Obsidian is arguably best known for its work on Fallout: New Vegas , it has a long and proud pedigree in the RPG genre. The developer's Pillars of Eternity games are particularly prominent CRPGs, which set the stage for the developer's recent first-person action RPG Avowed . Like a classic JRPG , Pillars of Eternity 2: Deadfire sees players gathering a party of fellow warriors and embarking on a quest to protect the world from the actions of a misguided deity.

Deadfire differs from its predecessor with its nautical focus; the game is set on an archipelago, and the protagonist must captain a ship in order to explore the new region and prepare to repel the god Eothas. The game's intricate world and complex political ecosystem make for a thorny web of challenges for JRPG fans to untangle.

5 Dragon Age: Origins

A Darker Dragon

Dragon Age: Origins
9 /10
13
9.6 /10
Released
November 3, 2009

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL
9 /10
13
9.6 /10

ESRB
M for Mature: Blood, Intense Violence, Language, Partial Nudity, Sexual Content
Powered by

JRPGs like Dragon Quest have a rich history of drawing on medieval fantasy; traditional images like armored knights, robed wizards, castles, and, of course, dragons are very common in many of these classic games. JRPG fans will find a similar setup in BioWare's Dragon Age franchise, which takes a dark fantasy approach to these classic stylings.

Dragon Age: Origins takes place in a world on the brink of destruction, where sinister demonic forces threaten to overwhelm civilization. Mages are ostracized and mistreated for the potential danger they pose, and society is fractured. Dragon Age fans have a lot of darkness to navigate, but classic RPG trappings are abundant around every corner, and BioWare's excellent character work shines through in the game's wide roster of companions.

4 Divinity: Original Sin 2

A World Of Possibility

Divinity: Original Sin 2
8.5 /10
Released
September 14, 2017

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
M for Mature: Blood and Gore, Language, Sexual Themes, Violence
Powered by

Divinity: Original Sin 2 is one of the most prominent CRPGs available, renowned not only for its engaging fantasy world and story but also for its complex and adaptive gameplay. JRPG fans will find a lot to love in assembling their party of heroes, including characters like a vengeance-bound dwarf, a lost immortal, and a woman possessed by a demon.

The game's turn-based action system is more intricate than the traditional JRPG approach, tasking players with fighting strategically in a fully interactive space. However, this in turn sets up a rich variety of ways for players to utilize the environment to their advantage. As characters develop and gain new abilities, the players controlling them can find new and creative ways to put them to use. This game is an excellent way to introduce newcomers to CRPGs, making it a perfect choice for JRPG fans who want to branch out.

3 Mass Effect: Legendary Edition

Saving The Galaxy

Mass Effect: Legendary Edition
9 /10
10
9.7 /10
Released
May 14, 2021

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL
9 /10
10
9.7 /10

ESRB
M for Mature: Blood, Drug Reference, Partial Nudity, Sexual Content, Strong Language, Use of Alcohol, Violence
Powered by

Very few JRPGs have shooting mechanics, let alone ones as refined and intricate as those found in the Mass Effect trilogy. However, BioWare has done an excellent job of incorporating a healthy and engaging layer of RPG mechanics into the game's shooting mechanics, providing an exciting experience that marries gunplay with the character progression RPG fans crave.

While players don't get direct control over their teammates like they might in a traditional JRPG, they can still call for specific abilities, which can turn the tide of combat if used properly. Mass Effect also has some of the most compelling NPC teammates in the industry, and deepening one's bonds with them is a deeply rewarding activity that should appeal to fans of JRPGs like Persona 5 .

2 Clair Obscur: Expedition 33

A Strange New World

10 Images
10 Images
Clair Obscur: Expedition 33
45
9.7 /10
Released
April 24, 2025

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL

ESRB
Mature 17+ // Blood and Gore, Strong Language, Suggestive Themes, Violence
Powered by

Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 is a very French video game, taking place in a twisted, dark fantasy version of the region's Belle Epoque era. While France heavily inspires the culture and architecture, the gameplay is pure JRPG. The developers have cited Final Fantasy and the Persona series as inspirations, and this influence is evident in the game's turn-based combat, as well as its interactive overworld map.

While Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 takes direct influence from JRPGs, it also stands apart due to its reactive combat. Players are encouraged to act fast to dodge and parry enemy blows, as well as hit quick-time events on their own abilities in order to maximize damage and healing. This keeps every fight fast and engaging, and lets players take on extremely powerful monsters if their reflexes are fast enough.

1 Baldur's Gate 3

Unforgettable Realms

Baldur's Gate 3
9 /10
125
9.7 /10
Released
August 3, 2023

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
9 /10
125
9.7 /10

ESRB
M for Mature: Blood and Gore, Partial Nudity, Sexual Content, Strong Language, Violence
Powered by

The impac t Baldur's Gate 3 has had on the RPG genre is undeniable. This game adapts the wildly popular 5th edition of D&D into a vast, expansive fantasy world, full of memorable characters and intense combat encounters. Players can sink dozens of hours and multiple playthroughs into the game and still not see everything it has to offer.

One of the most memorable things about Baldur's Gate 3 is its charming roster of party members. Each character is detailed and fleshed out enough to serve as a protagonist in their own right, and players can form bonds and even romances with them over the course of their travels. Whether a player grew up on JRPGs like Final Fantasy or more action-oriented titles like The Elder Scrolls , Baldur's Gate 3 is an ideal RPG for everyone.

item.title: Diablo 4 Season 8 Seems to Be Suffering from Major Memory Leak Issues
item.description:
Summary

  • Diablo 4 PC players facing memory leaks causing crashes.
  • Memory issues previously seen in past seasons resurfacing.
  • Blizzard expectantly working on fix for Season 8 bugs.

Diablo 4 players on PC are reporting memory leaks. The issue is being noticed a few days after the start of Diablo 4 's eighth season and is leading to frustrating situations.

This is not the first time Diablo 4 players have experienced high memory consumption on their PCs, resulting in poor performance and eventual game crashes. In 2023, players had VRAM problems that in some cases could only be solved by restarting the game. The same situation happened in Diablo 4 Season 7, and even players with high-spec PCs found it difficult to play for more than an hour before the game shut down completely. Memory leak problems are no stranger to the Diablo 4 community, and it looks like they're affecting players again.

Several Diablo 4 players are reporting memory leaks in the PC version. On Reddit, user CoolRatio9477 shared how their experience is being affected, saying that even if they stay idle in Diablo 4 's character selection screen, their PC is registering RAM spikes of between 15-20 GB. According to them, the problem is extending to VRAM as well, with portal and zone transitions causing usage to peak at 13-14 GB. The OP says he's experiencing crashes approximately every 30–45 minutes with the Fenris error, and the only way to release memory is by fully closing Diablo 4 .

High Memory Usage Is Haunting Diablo 4 Players on PC Again

CoolRatio9477 posted a bug report on the Blizzard forum, which has 89 posts from various players who are experiencing the same problem. Also on Reddit, user Blubbpaule said they are suffering from memory leaks that caused Diablo 4 to crash every 10 minutes. In the comments section, one player said that in Season 7 of Diablo 4 , their PC's RAM consumption was 19 GB, and in Season 8 it jumped to around 28 GB. Another Redditor shared a workaround that a player gave two years ago and involves changing the paging file size, which improved the experience for several community members.

The new RAM and VRAM leak hasn't been officially addressed yet, but with players starting to talk about it more, the expectation is that the devs will release a fix for it soon. This will allow players to have a more engaging experience with Diablo 4 Season 8, which started on April 29 and brought new content such as the return of Belial. Blizzard has also added Boss Powers, which works similarly to Witch and Vampiric Powers, and the Diablo 4 x Berserk crossover, with the game adding content based on Kentaro Miura's iconic manga.

Your comment has not been saved

item.title: Grand Theft Auto 6 Might Just Have Its Own Dutch Van Der Linde
item.description:
An award-winning game formula may seem easy to identify, but it may be deceivingly hard to capture. Striking graphics, hypnotizing gameplay, and an intriguing story can guarantee that players keep coming back for more. Grand Theft Auto 6 developer Rockstar Games is no stranger to this formula. Confident in its games’ presentation, Rockstar knows how to produce games that captivate a player’s attention for hundreds of hours. Its highly anticipated Grand Theft Auto 6 , releasing next year, already shows some signs that Rockstar Games has replicated the magic that makes a modern video game an instant classic. However, the creators of GTA 6 know all too well that the cherry on top of this successful formula is not necessarily unheard-of narratives or fantastical settings, but rather, it is compelling characters that wrap the bow neatly on a new game.

Rockstar Games’ portfolio of projects demonstrates a keen understanding of nuanced character writing. From Arthur Morgan to Trevor Phillips, Rockstar has established a pattern of respecting every character’s story, no matter how distant in tone. Every single main and supporting character comes to life through appropriate dialogue and adventurous character arcs, and GTA 6 characters will hopefully follow in those same footsteps. In Red Dead Redemption 2 , the team at Rockstar Games showed off serious writing chops with characters like Dutch van der Linde: an outlaw philosopher and tragic narcissist. Dutch stood as one of Rockstar’s most iconic creations. Now, Grand Theft Auto 6 may be introducing a new character cut from a similar cloth: Raul.

Raul is GTA 6’s High-Risk Mastermind

According to official material released by Rockstar, Raul is a seasoned bank robber known for his confidence, charm, and cunning. He’s always scouting for new talent willing to take on increasingly high-stakes heists. Raul’s experience and magnetic personality make him a natural leader. But much like Dutch van der Linde, that leadership comes with a cost. Rockstar notes that Raul is beginning to show signs of recklessness, escalating the danger with every job he takes on. Eventually, other GTA 6 characters will have to decide whether to keep following him or jump ship before everything falls apart.

The setup is already familiar to anyone who played Red Dead Redemption 2 . Dutch van der Linde started his journey as a calculated visionary and slowly unraveled into a liability, dragging others down with him. The parallels between Dutch and Raul are hard to ignore: both are charismatic leaders whose vision blurs into delusion, raising the emotional and ethical stakes for everyone around them. Rockstar has proven it can explore this kind of character arc with nuance. It’s no wonder fans are hoping Raul’s story will follow a similar, if uniquely modern, trajectory.

Rockstar’s Strength Lies in Its Moral Gray Areas

Part of what made Dutch van der Linde so unforgettable was that he wasn't purely good or evil. His downfall wasn't just about pride or greed; it was about idealism gone sour. His downfall could have served as excellent fodder for a Dutch van der Linde spin-off game. But if Raul is truly walking a similar path, GTA 6 could give players another complex figure to grapple with. Raul could be someone who isn’t just an antagonist or a mentor, but a person whose decisions force the player to reflect on their own or tread carefully.

This type of character development is especially potent in a game like Grand Theft Auto 6 , which is expected to offer a sprawling, narrative-rich open world Vice City setting that could be bigger than initially imagined. Raul’s descent, or rise, could be shaped not only by the game’s story but by how players engage with him. Raul is someone whose trustworthiness is in question, characterized by a blend of delusion and risk-taking. Such complexities help elevate GTA ’s satirical chaos into something more emotionally grounded. This promises, perhaps, that GTA 6 will take on a more tragic tone.

High Stakes for a New Generation of GTA Players

Raul’s introduction is also timely. Rockstar is clearly trying to recapture the magic that made Red Dead Redemption 2 such a critical success, particularly among players who crave emotional stakes similar to Red Dead Redemption 2 in their open-world games. Introducing a character like Raul could help GTA 6 connect not just with longtime fans, but also with a new generation of players who value narrative depth as much as explosive gameplay. GTA 6 has even made cities controversial, so it’s likely nudging over toward more serious writing in every aspect of its DNA.

Moreover, Raul might serve as a pivot point for the two confirmed protagonists of GTA 6 , Lucia and Jason. If he’s the leader pulling the strings or the catalyst for their criminal ambitions, his arc could shape the emotional core of the game. Much like Dutch gave definitive shape to Arthur’s story, Raul may act as the mirror that reveals the limits of loyalty, trust, and ambition.

A Familiar Blueprint, with New Possibilities

Of course, Grand Theft Auto is not Red Dead Redemption . The tone is sharper, the satire more biting, and the stakes more absurd and tailored to a wider audience. But Rockstar’s interest in complex characters transcends genre and tone. Raul may not end up as a carbon copy of Dutch, but if he becomes a figure players argue about, sympathize with, or rage against, he will have succeeded in continuing Rockstar’s tradition of unforgettable supporting leads. GTA 6 ’s latest trailer gives nods toward RDR2 , so it may just be a matter of time until those connections run deeper.

Dutch has the advantage of appearing across multiple Red Dead Redemption games, so it may be hard for Raul to measure up in that regard.
